page.title: 05ECOLOGY
page.content: SOMERSHAM'S CLIMATE IS FAIRLY DRY AS IT HAS ONE OF THE LOWEST AVERAGE RAINFALLS IN THE COUNTRY. THE FLAT OPEN EXPANSE OF LAND TO THE EAST LAYS SOMERSHAM OPEN TO THE SWEEPING EFFECTS OF THE WINDS WHICH BLOW OFF THE FENS. THE LAND, HOWEVER, IS VERY WET AS IT CONSISTS OF RECLAIMED LAND DRAINED BY MANY DYKES. THE DAMP AREAS ATTRACT BIRDS INCLUDING KINGFISHERS AND FLOCKS OF BEWICK SWANS. AS WELL AS MANY COMMON BIRDS, PHEASANTS, LAPWING AND KESTRELS ARE OFTEN SEEN. IN SOMERSHAM THERE IS A LAKE WITH BREEDING SWANS, MORHEN, GREAT CRESTED GREBE AND MALLARD DUCKS. IT IS USED FOR FISHING AND HAS CARP, ROACH, BREAM AND PIKE. A LARGE PIKE (27 LBS) HAS TAKEN SOME DUCKLINGS. TREES ROUND THE LAKE INCLUDE WILLOW, HAWTHORN AND MAPLE. AN OLD RAILWAY TRACK ATTRACTS WILD LIFE AND IS AN INTERESTING WALK.
